Reference¶

Style¶

Sets the theme of the tkinter.Tk instance and supports all ttkbootstrap and ttk themes provided. This class is meant to be a drop-in replacement for ttk.Style and inherits all of it’s methods and properties. Creating a Style object will instantiate the tkinter.Tk instance in the Style.master property, and so it is not necessary to explicitly create an instance of tkinter.Tk. For more details on the ttk.Style class, see the python documentation.

# instantiate the style with default theme *lumen*
style = Style()

# instantiate the style with another theme
style = Style(theme='superhero')

# available themes
for theme in style.theme_names():
    print(theme)
class ttkbootstrap.Style(theme='lumen', *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: tkinter.ttk.Style

A class for setting the application style.

__init__(theme='lumen', *args, **kwargs)[source]¶
Parameters

theme (str) – the name of the theme to use at runtime; lumen by default.

theme_use(themename=None)[source]¶

If themename is None, returns the theme in use, otherwise, set the current theme to themename, refreshes all widgets and emits a <<ThemeChanged>> event.

This method should be used when you want to change the theme after the window has already been created. Otherwise, the preferred method is to instantiate the window with a theme argument.

Parameters

themename (str) – the theme to apply when creating new widgets

Colors¶

A class that contains the theme colors as well as several helper methods for manipulating colors. This class is attached to the Style object at run-time for the selected theme, and so is available to use with Style.colors. The colors can be accessed via dot notation or get method:

# dot-notation
Colors.primary

# get method
Colors.get('primary')

This class is an iterator, so you can iterate over the main style color labels (primary, secondary, success, info, warning, danger):

for color_label in Colors:
    color = Colors.get(color_label)
    print(color_label, color)

If, for some reason, you need to iterate over all theme color labels, then you can use the Colors.label_iter method. This will include all theme colors, including border, fg, bg, etc…

for color_label in Colors.label_iter():
    color = Colors.get(color_label)
    print(color_label, color)
class ttkbootstrap.Colors(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: object

A collection of colors used in a ttkbootstrap theme.

Parameters

  • primary (str) – the primary theme color; is used as basis for all widgets

  • secondary (str) – an accent color; typically the same as selectbg in built-in themes

  • success (str) – an accent color; an orange hue in most themes

  • info (str) – an accent color; a blue hue in most themes

  • warning (str) – an accent color; an orange hue in most themes

  • danger (str) – an accent color; a red hue in most themes

  • bg (str) – background color; used for root window background

  • fg (str) – primary font color; used for labels and non-input related widgets

  • selectfg (str) – foreground color of selected text

  • selectbg (str) – background color of selected text background

  • light (str) – a color used for input widget background and trough color

  • border (str) – a color used on the border of several input widgets (combobox, entry, spinbox, etc…)

  • inputfg (str) – a color used for input widgets; typically a reverse lightness of fg

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

Return repr(self).

__weakref__¶

list of weak references to the object (if defined)

static brightness(hex_color, pct_change)[source]¶

Adjust the value of a given hexadecimal color. The percent change is expected to be a float.

To return a lighter color, use a positive floating value:

Colors.brightness('#fafafa', 0.15)

To return a darker color, use a negative floating value:

Colors.brightness('#fafafa', -0.15)
Parameters

  • hex_color (str) – hexadecimal color

  • pct_change (float) – a floating value

Returns

a lightened or darkened hexadecimal color value

Return type

str

set(color_label, color_value)[source]¶

Set a color property

Parameters

  • color_label (str) – the name of the color to be set (key)

  • color_value (str) – a hexadecimal color value

Example:

set('primary', '#fafafa')
